stream_context.summary: Kaze reviews and debates his styrofoam “normal map”/bump shading approach, gives a major rundown of a crayon/crafts-themed course (new star objectives and setpieces), iterates on craft-material props (mushrooms redesigned as paper plates/umbrellas), and begins planning a new “ice” platforming section—ultimately reconsidering it and pivoting toward a castle biome. He also discusses enemy/obstacle brainstorming, N64 rendering constraints (CPU-generated textures, per-orientation variants), and emulator limitations blocking newer F3DEX features.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a dense level-design rundown (multiple star objectives and setpieces), a key technical explanation of Kaze’s CPU-driven ‘normal map’ support on N64 with its orientation constraints, and a meaningful direction change: scrapping/rethinking the planned ice/snow section in favor of a castle biome.

findings.summary: Kaze’s styrofoam surface shading is effectively a camera-vector-based normal/bump illusion: he multiplies normal vectors with the camera vector, which creates dynamic-looking depth but is physically “incorrect” for reflective behavior and produces angle-dependent flatness and seams.

He states the N64 doesn’t support normal maps natively, so he added support by computing the lighting/normal-map-derived texture on the CPU and then having the GPU render it; the tradeoff is needing separate generated textures for each supported orientation/rotation, making non-cube/irregular geometry expensive to support.
findings.quote: The N64 does not have normal map support. I added the support. The texture is computed on the CPU, and then the GPU just has to render it. But that means I need to generate one texture for each orientation.

findings.summary: Course 14’s new structure: crayons as early props; a tilting bridge to a Luigi area; Luigi doodle NPC requests a yellow crayon; the player must retrieve and escort/carry it back to “draw the star.” The course also includes a sand/desert zone with pyramids, a pyramid interior now reserved for the red-coin section, and platforming via ‘googly-eyed’ swamp-like pads and paper springs.

A planned paper-plane setpiece star: a Yoshi doodle prompts collecting “silver stars” (or similar), then a rubber-band-launched paper plane carries Mario on a chaotic ride that loops back and slams into a wall, with a brief sightline to an 8-bit pipe if the player pays attention.

He identifies remaining star/area beats for the course (as of this stream): a hidden-entrance cave area, the 8-bit pipe star, and a final platforming segment intended to end at a Toad doodle (initially imagined as an ice/snow section).

Visual iteration on mushrooms: chat criticism that they read too low-res/rough leads Kaze toward a ‘paper umbrella’/paper-plate mushroom concept with dotted decals; he considers multi-texturing as a cheaper approach than layering many decals.

Kaze notes a pipeline constraint: certain advanced rendering approaches (he references newer F3DEX features) are effectively blocked because emulators aren’t fully compatible yet, which forces more conservative visual techniques if the hack must run broadly on emulation.
findings.quote: The problem with F3DEX stuff is that emulators haven't gotten there yet. So if I do F3DEX stuff, our stuff is not going to run on emulator.

findings.summary: Obstacle/enemy ideation for the upcoming platforming stretch: he considers scissors as an ‘unbeatable’ hazard but decides cardboard saw blades likely fit the silhouette/readability better; he also adds ideas like falling cardboard bridges that roll/spring back up and a rolling ‘lock’ platform segment (like the rolling logs/locks in Mario 64).

He rethinks the planned ice/snow biome due to asset/readability and cost concerns (e.g., cotton-ball snow being too expensive/high-poly) and decides mid-stream to pivot that section toward a castle biome instead—implying snow is cut and lava/volcano is deprioritized, while cave remains planned.
findings.quote: I think I'm changing this to a castle biome. And then snow area is gone. Lava area is also not really a thing anymore.

findings.summary: Team status snapshot: Kaze frames himself as the main developer, says Biobak is helping rework some levels, Badub is making most of the music, and Zeina is working on the overworld—emphasizing the overworld should be designed later because it ‘ties everything together’ once more of the game is known.

zeina.summary: Zeina is mentioned as actively working on the overworld; Kaze argues the overworld is best tackled later once the team has more information about the full game structure, because it’s the connective tissue.

findings.summary: Lilaa repeatedly pushes for clearer real-world craft readability (e.g., paper-grass ‘bushels’/Odyssey-like grass read, paper chains linking islands), and participates in the mushrooms/prop readability discussion that drives Kaze toward the paper-plate/umbrella mushroom solution.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Am I doomed to roam this earth just looking for textures all my life?
memorable_quotes.context: While searching for reference textures/materials again, he jokes about a recurring pattern of streams turning into texture hunts—useful as a character beat about the craft-material aesthetic being asset- and texture-driven.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: On the last day of elementary school… I said, I still hate it. I'm just doing it so you leave me alone.
memorable_quotes.context: Personal anecdote explaining his aversion to 2D drawing; ties directly into his later insistence that in-game doodles should look amateur rather than polished.

key_stories.title: Faking ‘normal maps’ on N64 for styrofoam mountains
key_stories.summary: Kaze tries to sell the craft-world look with convincing ‘styrofoam’ surfaces, but real normal mapping isn’t supported on N64. He implements a CPU-generated shading approach, then discovers it creates unwanted artifacts (flat angles, seams, sharp edges) and demands strict orientation management.
key_stories.challenge: Achieving dynamic, believable surface depth/reflectiveness for styrofoam-like mountains on N64 hardware constraints.
key_stories.process: He experiments with camera-vector-based shading, debates whether the result is a bump map vs normal map approximation, and weighs changes like bevels and additional orientations—while acknowledging limits like unsmoothed normals and visible edge lines.
key_stories.outcome: A workable but constrained technique: looks good from some angles, reads flat from others, and requires per-orientation texture generation—affecting how geometry can be built (blocky vs freely angled).
key_stories.key_quote: The N64 does not have normal map support. I added the support… I need to generate one texture for each orientation.

key_stories.title: Course 14 redesign into an escort-and-doodle star objective
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlines a more quest-like star: a Luigi doodle can’t finish a drawn star without a yellow crayon, turning the level into a retrieval-and-escort objective. This pushes the craft theme beyond visuals into gameplay structure (carrying items, returning to NPCs, drawing).
key_stories.challenge: Making the course feel like more than a visual diorama by adding objectives with friction, risk, and readable ‘craft’ interactions.
key_stories.process: He adds a tilting bridge to gate the Luigi area, plans enemy placement on the route, places a carryable yellow crayon pickup, and frames the payoff as completing the doodle/star drawing interaction.
key_stories.outcome: One star becomes a distinct “bring the crayon back” mission, and level layout is adjusted around that loop; other stars are redistributed (e.g., red coins moved inside the pyramid).

key_stories.title: Pivoting from an ice/snow section to a castle biome
key_stories.summary: While attempting to plan an icy platforming finale leading to a Toad doodle, Kaze struggles to find craft-material assets that read as ‘ice’ without being too expensive or unrealistic on N64. He ultimately decides to replace the concept with a castle biome, cutting the snow area and sidelining lava/volcano ideas.
key_stories.challenge: Finding a craft-material ‘ice’ language that is readable, performant, and content-rich enough to close the course.
key_stories.process: He researches snow diorama references, considers cotton balls (too costly), sugar cubes/ice landscapes, and even a volcano alternative—then reframes the missing biome coverage (grasslands, mountains, desert, but no castle/clouds).
key_stories.outcome: Decision made on-stream: convert the planned ice section to a castle biome; unresolved questions remain about what replaces the cut ice/lava beats and how the player reaches certain setpieces (e.g., paper plane).
key_stories.key_quote: I think I'm changing this to a castle biome. And then snow area is gone.

open_questions.context: Kaze’s CPU-generated ‘normal map’ look depends on orientation-specific textures and produces visible seams/sharp edges; he can’t smooth normals with the current approach and considers bevels that double orientation variants.
questions: What were your acceptance criteria for the styrofoam look—was it ‘physically correct’ lighting, or simply readability and vibe from typical gameplay angles?
How did you decide how many orientations were worth supporting (4 vs 8 vs more), and did that decision reshape how you built mountains and other non-cubic forms?
Did you ever consider limiting camera angles/level framing to hide artifacts, or was the goal to make the technique robust from any angle?

open_questions.topic: Emulator compatibility vs pushing rendering features (F3DEX)
open_questions.context: Kaze claims certain F3DEX advances would break emulator compatibility, creating a ceiling on visual experimentation if broad playability is a priority.
questions: Which specific F3DEX features were you tempted to use, and what visual problems would they have solved in this course?
How do you decide when to prioritize emulator compatibility over a better look (e.g., ‘runs everywhere’ vs ‘best possible’)?
Did you ever test a dual-render-path approach (fallback rendering), or is the maintenance cost too high for the team size?

open_questions.topic: Why castle replaced ice, and what the new craft language is
open_questions.context: Kaze pivots away from snow/ice due to lack of convincing, performant craft assets; he decides on a castle biome but hasn’t defined the asset kit or traversal to certain areas yet.
questions: What was the decisive moment that made you abandon the ice idea—performance, lack of good-looking materials, or gameplay not coming together?
What does ‘castle’ mean in the craft world: cardboard bricks, paper battlements, toy blocks, something else—and how do you keep it feeling handmade instead of generic Mario castle?
How did this pivot affect the star list and pacing for Course 14—did any objectives get cut, merged, or moved to other courses?
